channel.title: Thread executors
channel.description:
I started adding threads in my OOP project, but I have a question for this, I've read the Java tutorials on thread and came with something that seems very easy to use: [url=http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/concurrency/exinter.html]Executor Interfaces (The Java™ Tutorials > Essential Classes > Concurrency)[/url]
What I would like to know is: if I run a constant game tick, like Runescape does every 600ms, should I do with the (scheduleWithFixedDelay) or would it be bad to use it? It seems too easy and since I never worked with threads before, I would like feedback.

item.title: Thread executors
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Hash1, post:1, topic:484515”]I started adding threads in my OOP project, but I have a question for this, I’ve read the Java tutorials on thread and came with something that seems very easy to use: Executor Interfaces (The Java™ Tutorials > Essential Classes > Concurrency)

What I would like to know is: if I run a constant game tick, like Runescape does every 600ms, should I do with the (scheduleWithFixedDelay) or would it be bad to use it? It seems too easy and since I never worked with threads before, I would like feedback.[/quote]if you were using it for game ticks, you’d want scheduleAtFixedRate

Read full topic

item.title: Thread executors
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

Are you planning on using multiple threads in your project? Writing concurrent applications can be hard, especially for beginners. You can run into so many problems that are often hard to diagnose, this includes deadlocks.

As for using a ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor as a loop, it all depends. You may want control over the loop, rather than a per-determined amount of time between each tick.

Read full topic
